articles.title: Melbourne is the thunderstorm asthma capital of the world. And the pollen season is getting longer
articles.author: Wendy Tuohy
articles.summary: Melbourne is already the allergy capital of the world, with 31.8% of residents suffering from allergic rhinitis and thunderstorm asthma. University of Queensland scientists analysed three decades of airborne pollen data in Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra and found the pollen season is starting earlier and lasting longer.

articles.title: Aircraft trails above Santa Cruz
articles.author: Shmuel Thaler
articles.summary: A jet is leaving contrails in its wake as it flies northward over Santa Cruz. Scientists believe that contrail cloudiness may contribute to human-induced climate change. They are formed when ice particles form when they fall slowly and evaporate in the lower atmosphere.

articles.title: Birdwatching keeps citizen scientists 'happy and healthy' as they track species
articles.summary: Birdwatching has become more popular since the pandemic. Stephanie Chambers founded the Sydney Bird Club with her partner Amy Ranck in 2016. Dr Crystal D'Souza says birdwatching has a positive impact on people's mental health. Birdwatchers are essential to tracking bird populations across the country.

articles.title: Are cyclones worsening with climate change?
articles.author: Tom Wark
articles.summary: The definition of a tropical cyclone was changed in 1978. Storms that would have been classified as tropical cyclones were instead designated as sub-tropical systems. The decline in the category is due to the change in the definition of the storm system.

articles.title: Are cyclones worsening with climate change?
articles.author: Tom Wark
articles.summary: Ex-tropical Cyclone Alfred has unleashed online claims downplaying the way climate change affects the frequency and severity of major storms in Australia. The claims are not backed up by any scientific evidence.    i.e. they are not based on any scientific data.

articles.title: How climate change is making hay fever more miserable
articles.author: Maria Godoy
articles.summary: Climate change is making hay fever more miserable for allergy sufferers. Alisha Pershad saw it firsthand in her first year of medical school at George Washington University. She and her colleagues reviewed dozens of studies looking at the impact of climate change on hay fever sufferers' symptoms.

articles.title: Goa's vanishing coastline: 27% of beaches severely eroded as tourism, climate pressures mount
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: Goa's beaches are under threat from coastal erosion. Pernem taluka in North Goa is the most affected area, with erosion affecting 41-46% of its coastline. Salcete taluka follows closely, with 18-38% of the coastline affected by erosion. Goa government has established a 15-member expert committee in March 2025. The committee has been tasked with formulating a comprehensive mitigation strategy.

articles.title: Belize on the Brink: Climate Change Threatens Coastlines, Culture, and Food Security
articles.author: hipolito
articles.summary: A new report by the International Institute for Sustainable Development (IISD) warns of worsening impacts from climate change in Belize. The report focuses on the Maya Forest Corridor, Glover's Reef Marine Reserve, and South Water Caye Marine Reserve. Belize is highly vulnerable to climate hazards, including sea level rise and increasingly intense hurricanes. National adaptation plans are also underway.

articles.title: Satellite Infrared Shows Unusual Warm Pockets in Arctic Ocean
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: Satellite infrared imagery has recently revealed warm pockets scattered across the Arctic Ocean. This phenomenon raises questions about the future of our planet's climate and the delicate balance of ecosystems in the Arctic region. Let's dive into the fascinating world of satellite technology and explore what these warm pockets might mean for Arctic Ocean and beyond.

articles.title: Prince George Fire Centre gearing up for another wildfire season
articles.author: Zachary Barrowcliff
articles.summary: April is the start of wildfire season for the Prince George Fire Centre. There have been five fires in the PG Fire Centre since April 1st. The biggest factor going into the wildfire season is the precipitation as we remain in a multi-year ongoing drought. This weekend is forecast to have winds up to 70 kph.

articles.title: Heat action plans need better focus
articles.author: Jitendra Choubey
articles.summary: The Indian Meteorological Department predicted an increase in heat wave days and higher-than-normal temperatures from April to June. Last year, there were more than 733 deaths and over 40,000 cases of heat stroke across 17 states. Outdoor workers in India are the most affected by heat, eating into their working hours by 20%. This decline impacts household economies and the country's GDP. Three-fourths of India's labour force is exposed to extreme heat. The country developed its first Heat Action Plan (HAP) in 1999.

articles.title: Asia-Pacific Climate Change Impact Assessed in UN Economic Survey
articles.author: Editor Oil Price.com
articles.summary: Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia are well positioned at present to confront future challenges related to climate change, according to the UN report. However, the South Caucasus states are not well positioned for institutional capacity to address climate challenges. The study predicts an average 1 basis point increase in the consumer price index due to expected climate change by mid-century.

articles.title: Weather: Sunny start to school holidays for NZ but heavy rain could move in from Wednesday
articles.author: Ben Leahy
articles.summary: Temperatures in Christchurch should reach 19C today and 22C on Monday. It will drop to 13C on Tuesday and Wednesday, but it will be mostly fine for holidays.   for the rest of the week, however, the temperature will drop dramatically.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Gitanyow chiefs tell B.C. court LNG project threatens salmon rights
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: According to the UN's intergovernmental panel on climate change, human activities like burning fossil fuels and farming livestock are the main drivers of climate change. The past 10 years (2015-2024) are the 10 warmest on record. The Earth is now about 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s.

articles.title: Low pressure over Odisha: How do they form and why are they unusual this summer?
articles.author: Mohammed Imteshal Karim
articles.summary: The summer of 2025 has been marked by an anomalous weakening of low-pressure systems over Odisha. Several factors have contributed to this phenomenon, including persistent heatwaves, dry air intrusion, and lack of supportive atmospheric conditions. El Nino-Southern Oscillation plays a pivotal role in influencing weather patterns across the Indian subcontinent.

articles.title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS: What's happening, or not, in the Alabama Swamps
articles.author: Douglas H. Domedion
articles.summary: The main waterfowl migration is over. Tundra swans have headed back to their nesting grounds in the Arctic tundra country. Large masses of migrating Canada geese have also headed farther north. The ospreys are back and are working on their nests. Hooded mergansers are still in the area. Wood ducks are visiting the flooded area in my woods.

articles.title: Critical Water Scarcity Poses Threat to the Caribbean, according to CAF study.
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: CAF – Development Bank of Latin America and the Caribbean has conducted a study on the water security challenges facing Barbados and the Eastern Caribbean. CAF convened a High-Level Technical Workshop on Water and Sanitation in the Caribbean in Bridgetown, Barbados on April 8-9, 2025 to discuss the findings of the study and develop an actionable roadmap for addressing the challenges.

articles.title: Searching for New-Age Solutions
articles.author: Krishna Gupta
articles.summary: In the coming articles, we will discuss various issues related to Adaptation. Developing countries have been pushing for giving equal importance to adaptation measures in the various Conference of Parties (COPs). The agriculture sector will continue to be the mainstay for food security in the near future. It is necessary to protect it from the adverse effects of climate change. The use of innovative technology and AI is likely to play an important factor in these efforts.

articles.title: Pollen season getting longer
articles.author: Metro Creative Connection
articles.summary: There are more frost-free days, warmer seasonal air temperatures, and greater amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere because of climate change. This has led to higher concentrations of pollen in the air and longer pollen seasons, which is increasing the intensity of the pollen season.

articles.title: Traffic Noise Provokes ‘Road Rage' In Male Galápagos Warblers
articles.author: Grrl Scientist
articles.summary: Galapagos Yellow Warbler near busy roads is becoming more aggressive because of human noise pollution. The Galápagos Islands are home to many species of birds and animals that are found nowhere else in the world. The islands were visited by Charles Darwin in 1835 when he was 22 years old. The population of the islands is growing and so is the number of vehicles on the islands' roads. Yellow Warblers are the most common victims of road traffic.

articles.title: Caribbean Matters: A spotlight on who's fighting to save the planet
articles.author: Denise Oliver Velez
articles.summary: Caribbean Matters is a weekly series from Daily Kos. This week's topic is climate change and the environment. U.S. needs to deal with environmental issues here at home as well as in the neighboring Caribbean region. The Nature Conservancy and The Fish 'N Fins Inc. are leading the charge on this issue.

articles.title: Road users advised to avoid Glenshane Road in Dungiven due to gorse fire
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: There is a gorse fire in the area of Glenshane Road in Dungiven. Road users are advised to avoid the area. The fire is burning on the Gorse Road.    - for confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: The Climate Has Changed on Climate Change
articles.author: Joel Kotkin
articles.summary: Trump's decision to withdraw from the green mantra is hubristic, according to some climate activists. They think it's like an ostrich sticking it's head in the ground.    -      for the sake of the environment.

articles.title: With Trump and climate change, denial is a hell of a drug
articles.summary: The next National Climate Assessment report is due in two years, but the White House has cut funding for the group that produces it. It's easier to claim climate change is a hoax if there's no definitive report with empirical research saying otherwise. The Trump administration is trying to put hundreds of scientists out of work.

articles.title: 'Stop Building on the Beach' – Fletcher's Climate Alarm
articles.author: Tony Nicholas
articles.summary: Dr James Fletcher is the Caribbean Community's climate envoy and former minister responsible for sustainable development in Saint Lucia. He urges the tourism industry to stop building beachfront hotels because of rising sea levels, climate change, biodiversity loss, and economic instability. He calls for a shift toward 'regenerative' tourism.

articles.title: Indian Cities Scorching Like Pressure Cookers: How To Tackle The Urban Heat Island Effect
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: Urban heat island effect (UHI) is the localized warming of cities versus the rural areas surrounding them. UHI is a climate issue but also has significant public health implications and exemplifies urban growth that is not sustainable. It is usually very hot during summer in urban settlements due to the heating up on the sun and human activities.

articles.title: Trailing arbutus will be tardy this spring
articles.author: LINDA TYSSEN COLUMNIST
articles.summary: The temperature this morning of April 7 was 13 degrees. It brought to mind the year Mother picked arbutus around this time. In 2023, I wrote a column entitled 'Arbutus, the trailing treasure of spring' and I reprint it here.

articles.title: Barrage of news shows climate change policy is rapidly shifting under Trump administration
articles.author: Dinah Voyles Pulver
articles.summary: The National Climate Assessment, a Congressionally mandated, scientific review published every few years, is in doubt because of the Trump administration's anti-science agenda. NASA ended its contract with the ICF International consulting firm to provide staff support. The Department of Commerce announced a $4 million cut in contract agreements with Princeton University for a long-standing partnership at one of the world's leading atmospheric science laboratories. President Donald Trump also signed an executive order directing the Attorney General to investigate state and local laws that address climate change.

articles.title: Letter to Editor: Sea Level Rise Hits a BRIC Wall
articles.author: Letter to Editor
articles.summary: Communities along the Eastern Shore have been planning for sea level rise for the last several years. They have spent thousands of dollars preparing studies and plans to combat projected increases in Chesapeake Bay water levels due to sea-level rise and storm surge events. The federal program called Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities (BRIC) provided construction funds to states. It was supposed to be used to help communities prepare for future flood events. President Trump's Homeland Security Secretary Noem abruptly ended the program on April 4, 2025.

articles.title: Bad News for Man's Best Friend: Dogs Are Environmental Villains
articles.author: Donna Lu
articles.summary: Dogs have 'extensive and multifarious' environmental impacts, disturbing wildlife, polluting waterways and contributing to carbon emissions. Australian review of existing studies has argued that 'the environmental impact of owned dogs is far greater, more insidious, and more concerning than is generally recognised'. The dry pet food industry had an environmental footprint of around twice the land area of the UK, with greenhouse gas emissions up to 151 Mt CO2.

articles.title: You're Not Imagining It: Your Pollen Allergies Are Lasting Longer
articles.author: Aynsley O’Neill
articles.summary: Because of global warming, the pollen allergy season in the United States is three weeks longer now than it was 50 years ago. Dr. Neelima Tummala is an ear, nose and throat physician at NYU Langone Health. About 20 percent of Americans suffer from pollen allergies.

articles.title: UPDATE: Beach hazards statement in place for Orange County Coastal until Saturday night
articles.author: CA Weather Bot
articles.summary: Beach hazards statement is in effect until 11 p.m. for Orange County Coastal. Elevated surf of 3 to 6 feet with local sets to 7 feet and dangerous rip currents expected. NWS advises people to stay out of the water to avoid hazardous swimming conditions.

articles.title: More than $100M possible for Maine's winter storm, climate change prep
articles.author: Penelope Overton
articles.summary: The House and Senate took initial votes on a $34.5 million bill to fund statewide home resiliency grants, improve the emergency communication system and create a new state resilience office. On Thursday, the Appropriations and Financial Affairs Committee held a hearing on a proposed $75 million bond to invest in coastal resilience projects, with a special focus on protecting Maine's sandy beaches from being washed away by sea level rise and storm surge.

articles.title: NATURE NOTES: Birds instinctively know when to migrate
articles.summary: In the spring, birds begin their migration from southern regions to northern regions to prepare for the breeding season. Birds rely on a mix of instincts, environmental cues and navigation mechanisms to know when and where to migrate, some of which still puzzle scientists to this day. Birds use the sun, the stars, earth's magnetic field and landmarks to help guide them on their long journeys.

articles.title: Exeter researcher warns of rising crop pests due to climate change
articles.author: Kelly Henaughen
articles.summary: Climate change and globalisation are causing a rise in crop pests, a study has found. About 40 per cent of global crop production is currently lost to pests and diseases. Extreme weather events like heatwaves and droughts can trigger pest outbreaks. The paper highlights that crop pests are likely to become more prevalent in higher latitudes.

articles.title: Letters to the Editor, April 12, 2025
articles.author: Postmedia News
articles.summary: There's a lot of things wrong with today's world that are caused by us, or at least those who represent us. Recent weather patterns are receiving attention for the damage caused by climate change. Liberal policies have ruined many aspects of this country and Carney is going to willfully carry on them.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning over threats facing newly discovered creatures: 'Literally running out of space'
articles.author: Cody Januszko
articles.summary: Two new species of Whirring Tree Frogs were recently discovered in Australia. They are native to Eastern Australia's moist, cool, upland environment. Scientists warn that they may not be able to adapt to climate change. They need to preserve their habitats and prevent their extinction.

articles.title: Punjab's Groundwater Crisis
articles.author: Mohsin Leghari
articles.summary: Punjab's groundwater supplies are disappearing at an alarming rate. Two landmark laws-the Punjab Irrigation, Drainage and Rivers Act, 2023 and the Punjab Water Act, 2019-offer powerful tools to combat this emergency. The World Bank warns of a 6% GDP loss by 2047 and 20-30% by 2030.

articles.title: Oman's Agriculture: Challenges, Innovations, and Future Directions - The Arabian Stories News
articles.summary: Oman has some of the most extreme environmental conditions for agriculture globally. Only 4.6% of the country's territory is suitable for cultivation. 80% of Oman is desert or semi-desert, with limited arable land suitable for conventional farming. The region's agricultural landscape is characterized by remarkable geographical diversity across five distinct agricultural zones.

articles.title: UFO Over Central West, NSW, Australia, April 10, 2025, UAP Drone Sighting News. 👽👽👽
articles.author: Scott Waring
articles.summary: Scott C. Waring reports a UFO sighting over Central West, Australia on April 10, 2025. Eyewitness reports that the object was moving smoothly and moving through clouds. There were no nearby flights on radar and the object made no sound. It was heading east.

articles.title: Trump administration seeks severe cuts to NOAA climate research, risking global impact
articles.summary: Trump administration wants to severely cut back the research arm of a government agency that plays a pivotal role in global climate science. About 75 per cent of funding for NOAA's research branch could be eliminated from the 2026 budget. Zoe Lofgren, the ranking Democrat on the House science committee, warns that the administration is 'wholly destroying' essential services.

articles.title: Int'l workshop on climate change and water safety effects along CPEC begins
articles.author: APP
articles.summary: The International Training Workshop on Climate Change and Water Safety Effects along the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) was inaugurated today at the Pakistan Academy of Sciences in Islamabad. The five-day workshop has drawn more than 120 participants from leading academic and research institutions across Pakistan and 20 international delegates from the Hindu Kush Himalaya region, including China, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Afghanistan.

articles.title: NOAA research labs in crosshairs as Trump seeks to cut climate spending
articles.summary: 75 percent of funding for NOAA's research branch could be eliminated from the 2026 budget. The administration wants to eliminate the jobs of hundreds of federal and academic scientists who study human-driven global warming. Zoe Lofgren, the ranking Democrat on the House science committee, warned that the administration is 'wholly destroying' essential services.

articles.title: NOAA reports March 2025 as third warmest on record
articles.author: Adam Strzempko
articles.summary: March 2025 was one of the warmest Marches on record across the world. It was 2.36 degrees above the 20th century average temperature. This month in western Massachusetts, temperatures have been running below the average for the month. According to Climate Central, in the Springfield area, the average temperature for March has increased by 2.4 degrees since 1970.

articles.title: Seeing Australia's beloved gumtrees dying makes my insides knot. If they can't survive, how can we?
articles.author: Jess Harwood
articles.summary: Dr Dean Nicolle has been planting eucalypts on a block of land south of Adelaide since 1993. He is conducting drought studies on his trees, about a third of which are dying or have curled up and died in the last few months. Australia is in the grip of its worst drought in 40 years. The IUCN has warned that 25% of eucalys are at risk of extinction.

articles.title: Video shows how quickly fire spread in South Carolina front lawn
articles.author: Good Morning America
articles.summary: NOAA data shows South Carolina had its driest first three months of the year in nearly 40 years, according to new data from NOAA's Climate Prediction Center. The state had its wettest January and February in 40 years according to NOAA's data.

articles.title: ‘Underwater Bushfire' Devastating Reefs yet to Let Up
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Half of Western Australia's coastline, including the UNESCO World Heritage-listed Ningaloo, has been hit by unprecedented heat stress up to two times worse than has ever been recorded, according to the Australian Corals Research Institute. The heat stress is affecting the corals.

articles.title: Seeing Australia's beloved gumtrees dying makes my insides knot. If they can't survive, how can ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Even the hardy eucalypts are finding their limits as we experience more frequent bushfires, heatwaves and droughts. Get Guardian Australia environment editor Adam Morton's Clear Air column as an e-mail. The series is called Last Chance: the extinction crisis being ignored this election.

articles.title: Greece's Must-See Archaeological Sites Before Climate Change Wins
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Climate change threatens Greece's archaeological sites. Rising seas and extreme weather endanger iconic sites like Delos and the Acropolis. Some of the incredible archaeological sites in Greece have witnessed the rise and fall of empires and once echoed with the footsteps of great people.

articles.title: Canada will no longer cover travel costs of experts it nominates to UN's climate science body
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: The federal government has stopped covering the travel costs of Canadian experts volunteering for the next major global climate science assessment. The change is a change from previous decades.    .      in a sudden and unexplained change from the previous decades, the government stopped covering travel costs for Canadian experts.

articles.title: Tropical Cyclone Errol likely to form off north coast of Western Australia this weekend
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Weather bureau predicts above-average temperatures across south-east Australia due to high-pressure system. Get our afternoon election email, free app or daily news podcast to stay up-to-date with the election campaign in Australia.    e.g. Election 2025 live updates.

articles.title: The great glacier meltdown has begun — and it's coming for our rivers
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The mountains, glaciers and alpine snowpacks support the freshwater needs of over half the world's population. A newly released United Nations report launched to mark the first-ever World Day for the protection of the environment has warned that the glaciers and mountains are melting.

articles.title: Asia-Pacific Climate Change Impact Assessed in UN Economic Survey
articles.author: Oil Price
articles.summary: The impact of climate change is moderate so far for the countries of the South Caucasus, according to a study. It is due to the macroeconomic and climate change nexus.    - The study is titled "Macroeconomic and Climate Change nexus"

articles.title: J.A. BOLTON: Is our climate changing?
articles.author: J.A. BOLTON
articles.summary: According to scientists, the average temperatures of the planet are rising. There seems to be no fall or spring weather anymore, it goes from hot summer overnight to mild winter overnight and then back to warm winter. Every year N.C. and other parts of the east coast see floods, winds and major droughts.
